ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I gained and improved my understanding of elementary German, including speaking, reading, writing, and listening. I also developed other useful skills, such as critical thinking, synthesis of information, reading and analyzing passages in a foreign language, and speaking freely and spontaneously.
Developed skills in grammatical structures and vocabulary in German, as well as some emphasis on cultural, geographical, and historical information.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The strengths of this course were the explanations provided in class and asynchronous videos of important content related to the language, such as grammar. The homework problems, asynchronous assignments, and projects in the course supplemented learning in the live lectures, and helped me improve my understanding of what was being taught in class. There were no major weaknesses of this course.

This course offered a lot of different methods for practicing German. Due to the combination of workbook activities, emails with pen-pals, in-class discussions, exams, and group projects, we were able to practice our reading, writing, listening and speaking skills. The course was also extremely well organized and facilitated student learning. The only weakness was that the workload sometimes felt unnecessarily excessive.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The live virtual classes were successful, and allowed and fostered virtual engagement by all the students in the class. The video explanations during asynchronous days, as well as the accompanying assignments or readings were also successful, although the workload during the asynchronous assignments was sometimes overwhelming, but this was improved from the previous semester's class.

The use of breakout rooms allowed us to practice German in smaller groups. The activities, both inside and outside of class, worked well virtually. Overall, I think this course succeeded online and there were not any issues.

I believe that the alternating live and asynchronous work days worked very well for online classes and that time was very effectively used during live seminars. Because of the heavy audio compression of zoom I believe more time could have been spent focusing on pronunciation, as it is often difficult to pick up over video call.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, I would recommend this course to another student. It was a very engaging course with a workload and intellectual challenge very similar to other Yale College courses. It was an excellent way to continue learning German as a continuation to the L1 course, and it fostered active participation from students in the course. The course is also small enough in order for each student to be able to participate multiple times in a single class.

I would recommend this course to a student who wants to learn German. I would warn them that it is a lot of work. However, if you are eager to study German and are ready to put in the effort, this course is a great way to learn.

I would recommend this course to other students. The department is very enthusiastic about teaching the language and always willing to give extra help. The course requires a lot of work, but that is true of any language and the course is well structured to allow students to succeed.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: There were 3 live virtual meetings on Zoom per week. There were also 2 days of asynchronous assignments per week. The exams were usually held on the asynchronous days, with the exception of the last one, which took place during a live virtual class.
Alternating live virtual seminars and asynchronous guided work days
